Haji and Al-Hajj

In Urdu and Bengali, a person who performs the Hajj pilgrimage is commonly called a Haji. The original Arabic word is Haaj (حاج) or Al-Haaj (الحاج). In Bengali, the word 'Al-Hajj' is used, and it simply means 'one who has performed Hajj.'

There's a misconception that a person who has performed Hajj once is a 'Haji,' while someone who has performed it multiple times is titled 'Al-Hajj.' This idea is incorrect. Both words can be used for someone who has performed Hajj just once.

The True Purpose of Hajj

Beyond this linguistic point, it's crucial for everyone to remember that Hajj is a significant pillar of Islam and a virtuous act of worship that should be performed solely to please Allah.

Performing Hajj to gain the title of 'Haji' or 'Al-Hajj,' or desiring this title after the pilgrimage, is a form of Riya (showing off). This intention corrupts the purpose of the worship and destroys its spiritual benefits. The true reward of Hajj is in seeking Allah's pleasure, not in seeking worldly titles or recognition.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, April-2007, www.alkawsar.com

Is it forbidden to light a fire in a house where someone has passed away?

No, it is not. There is a superstition in some regions that it's inauspicious to light a fire for three days after someone's death. This belief is completely baseless and wrong.

Islam does not allow for superstitions or believing in bad omens. There is nothing inauspicious about lighting a fire for normal household activities. The fact that fire is used to heat water for the deceased's ritual bath in many places proves how flawed this superstition is.

Instead of this baseless belief, Islam offers a compassionate solution for the grieving family. The Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) instructed neighbors and relatives to prepare and send food for the deceased's family for one day and one night. This is because the family is in a state of mourning and may not be able to cook for themselves. This guidance is based on human empathy and not on any superstition. The idea that lighting a fire is forbidden is, therefore, entirely unfounded.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, April-2007, www.alkawsar.com

Is it impermissible to recite Salawat (Durud) without Wudu?

Some people believe that it is necessary to perform Wudu (ablution) before reciting Salawat (blessings upon the Prophet). This idea is incorrect. One can recite Salawat with or without Wudu. It is not right to refrain from reciting Salawat based on this misconception. You should recite Salawat whenever you get the opportunity, regardless of your state of Wudu.

Similarly, Wudu is not a condition for reciting the Quran, but it is necessary to touch the Holy Quran. However, it is not permissible to recite the Quran when in a state of major ritual impurity (for which Ghusl is required). Therefore, it is discouraged to remain in this state for a long time without a valid reason. It is desirable to perform Ghusl and purify oneself as quickly as possible.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, June-2007, www.alkawsar.com

Do people go blind if they miss the Duha prayer?

No, that's not true. This is a baseless superstition.

Understanding the Duha Prayer

The Hadith mentions many virtues of the Duha prayer (Salat al-Duha), also known as the Chast prayer. A common misconception is that this prayer must consist of eight rak'ahs (units), which discourages some people from performing it. The truth is that the number of rak'ahs is not fixed; even by praying just two rak'ahs, one can attain its full rewards.

The Myth of Going Blind

Another widely circulated but completely false belief is that "if someone starts performing the Duha prayer and later stops, they will go blind." This idea has no basis in Islamic teachings and is considered a whisper from Shaytan (Satan) to prevent people from gaining the immense rewards of this prayer. This superstition has even led some women to mistakenly believe that only elderly women who no longer have their menstrual cycle can pray Duha.

The Importance of Good Deeds

A key principle in Islam is that any good deed, no matter how small, is a great blessing. It is wrong to avoid a voluntary prayer based on these unfounded excuses. This is simply a trick of Shaytan to deprive a person of a rewarding act of worship.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, June-2007, www.alkawsar.com

A Serious Conceptual Mistake

Does Islam have no guidance on culture?

Some people mistakenly believe that Islam has nothing to say about culture. This is a false idea. Islam is a complete way of life, and it includes a comprehensive culture of its own. When someone embraces Islam, their religion becomes Islam, and their culture becomes Islamic culture.

Islam does not forbid regional customs that are not against its teachings. For example, if speaking Bengali, wearing a lungi, or eating rice and fish are considered part of Bengali culture, a Muslim doesn't have to give them up after converting, as these practices don't conflict with Islamic principles.

However, when it comes to annual festivals, Islam has a different policy. When the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) came to Medina, he replaced the two local festivals with Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha. He clearly said, "Allah has given you two better festivals in exchange for them." This shows that a Muslim should not celebrate other religious or ethnic festivals because Eid is their only festival.

A dangerous misconception is that some people believe they can celebrate certain festivals as a "Bengali" and others as a "Muslim." This is completely wrong. After embracing Islam, a person's only identity is that of a Muslim, and their culture is Islamic. Those who think Islam is just a collection of religious acts misunderstand both Islam and the meaning of culture.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, June-2007, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Mistake: Delaying Prayer

Some people, particularly women, delay their obligatory prayers even after the time for the prayer has begun. They do so because they believe they should not pray until the men have returned from the mosque or the congregational prayer has ended. This idea is a misconception.

The truth is, just as men can pray as soon as the prayer time begins, so can women. Waiting for the men to return from the mosque is not a valid reason to delay prayer and miss the Mustahab (recommended) time for it.

The same rule applies to the Friday prayer. Women do not have to wait for the men to finish their Friday prayer and return home to perform their Zhuhr prayer. They can perform their prayer as soon as the time for it begins.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, July-2007, www.alkawsar.com

A Historical Error

Was Hasan al-Basri a Sahabi?

Some people mistakenly believe that Hasan al-Basri (may Allah have mercy on him) was a Sahabi (a companion of the Prophet Muhammad). This is a completely unfounded belief. While Hasan al-Basri was a great scholar and a significant figure in Islamic history, he was not a Sahabi; he was a Tabi'i (a successor, or one who met a Sahabi).

Hasan al-Basri was born towards the end of the caliphate of Umar ibn al-Khattab (may Allah be pleased with him), not during the lifetime of the Prophet Muhammad. He was only fourteen years old when the third caliph, Uthman ibn Affan (may Allah be pleased with him), was martyred in 35 AH. Given these historical facts, the idea that he was a Sahabi has no basis. Any accounts in books like Tazkirat al-Awliya or similar works claiming he was a Sahabi are considered fabricated and baseless.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, July-2007, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Religious Ruling

The Prayer Mat Du'a

The common belief that the du'a ("Inni wajjahtu wajhi...") found in some elementary religious books is to be recited before the Takbiratul Ihram (the opening takbir of prayer) is incorrect. This practice is not supported by any authentic Hadith.

The Correct Practice

In reality, this du'a is recited after the Takbiratul Ihram, specifically as a form of Thana (glorification of Allah) during the Tahajjud (optional night) prayer. It was an act the Prophet (PBUH) would perform occasionally.

For the regular obligatory prayers, the well-known and authenticated Thana is "Subhanakallahumma".

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, July-2007, www.alkawsar.com

A Conceptual Error

Is Spreading Knowledge of Supererogatory Acts Also Optional?

Islamic rulings are divided into categories: Fard (obligatory), Wajib (necessary), and Nafl (supererogatory) or Mustahab (recommended). Unfortunately, Nafl and Mustahab acts are often neglected because people believe there is no sin in omitting them. This mindset focuses on the negative aspect—the lack of punishment—rather than the positive aspect of earning great rewards.

A Grave Mistake

A more significant error is the belief that teaching others about these Nafl acts and proper etiquette (adab) is also an optional, or Nafl, duty. As a result, people may not take this responsibility seriously, and some even view those who do as being overly strict.

A Collective Obligation

According to Islamic law, this idea is incorrect. The duty to teach, practice, and promote matters of Nafl and adab is a Fard Kifayah—a collective obligation. This means that if a sufficient number of people within the community undertake this responsibility, the entire community is exempt from sin. However, if no one fulfills this duty, then the entire community will be held accountable.

This point was clearly explained by Imam Muhammad ibn al-Hasan al-Shaybani (may Allah have mercy on him) in his book Kitab al-Kasb, where he provided extensive evidence to support this view.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, July-2007, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Belief

Can a mother not eat after Asr if her child dies?

Some people hold the baseless belief that if a woman loses a child, she cannot eat or drink anything, not even tea or betel leaves, between the time of Asr and Maghrib for 40 days. It is said that doing so is a sin and will prevent her from having more children in the future.

This is a superstition born of ignorance. It has no basis in religious or worldly matters. The idea that eating or drinking at that time will cause a woman to be infertile is completely untrue. There are many mothers who have lost children and never followed or even heard of such a rule, yet they have been blessed with more children.

It's crucial to stay away from such false beliefs.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, August-2007, www.alkawsar.com

It's Not a Hadith

Are There Separate Duas for Each Part of Wudu?

In some prayer books, there are specific duas for washing each part of the body during wudu (ablution). This has led to the misconception that these are from the Sunnah or are ma’thur (reported from the Prophet).

This idea is incorrect. There is no reliable Islamic tradition or Hadith that provides a different dua for each individual limb during wudu. While there are authentic duas for before and after wudu, the ones for each specific step are not from a verified source.

Understanding the Status of the Duas

You should be aware that considering these duas as being from the Prophet is a mistake. However, since the meanings of these duas are generally good, it is not impermissible to recite them simply as a general form of remembrance of Allah, as long as you do not believe they are part of the Prophet's practice.

The Correct Approach

It is crucial to remember that these are not authentic duas of wudu. True Sunnah prayers and supplications are well-known and can be found in established Hadith collections. Focusing on what is authentically reported is the correct approach to Islamic practice.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, August-2007, www.alkawsar.com

A Surprising Misconception

Does a Wife's Saying Her Husband's Name Cause a Divorce?

Some women, particularly in certain regions, hold the astonishing belief that saying their husband's name is such a serious offense that it can cause a divorce. As surprising as this may sound, it's not impossible for such ideas to exist in a society where religious knowledge is not widespread.

While it is important for a wife to respect her husband—and calling him by his first name might be considered disrespectful in some cultures—the idea that simply saying his name causes a divorce is completely baseless. There is absolutely no foundation for this belief in Islamic law.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, August-2007, www.alkawsar.com

Superstitions

Is it Inauspicious to Sell Needles at Night?

A friend of mine in Dhaka recently went to a store at night to buy a needle. The young shopkeeper hesitated, looking to an older man for guidance, asking if it was okay to sell a needle at night. Thankfully, the older man dismissed the idea, stating that it was just a superstition.

This incident shows how deeply ingrained these types of baseless superstitions are in our society. It's sad that these unfounded beliefs often influence people's daily actions more than their actual religious convictions. There are countless such illogical notions, and they are not limited to the uneducated or rural communities; they are surprisingly common even among educated city dwellers.

It is crucial to openly discuss these issues. Even though some of these superstitions are specific to certain regions or social classes, they represent a significant problem in our society as a whole.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, August-2007, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Belief

What Was the Purpose of the Mi'raj?

When discussing the Mi'raj (the Prophet's ascension), some people suggest that its purpose was for Allah to invite the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) as a guest to His 'home.' This belief is incorrect, as Allah is not bound by a physical location or time. He created space and time and is beyond their limitations.

The Quran, in Surah Al-Isra and Surah An-Najm, clearly states the true purpose of the Mi'raj. The journey was intended to show the Prophet the great signs of Allah's power in the upper realms. It was a journey to witness and experience the divine manifestations of Allah's might and majesty.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, August-2007, www.alkawsar.com

A Historical Msconception

Where Did Pharaoh Drown?

Pharaoh drowned in the Red Sea, not the Nile River. This is a common historical and geographical misconception, likely because Pharaoh was the ruler of Egypt, which is famous for the Nile.

When Prophet Moses (PBUH) and his followers arrived at the sea, Allah commanded him to strike the water with his staff. The sea then parted, creating a dry path for them to cross. When Pharaoh and his army pursued them along the same path, the waters came back together, drowning Pharaoh and his entire army.

This event took place in the northern part of the Red Sea, which is now known as the Gulf of Suez, located between Egypt and the Sinai Peninsula.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, November-2007, www.alkawsar.com

Is the 27th Night Laylat al-Qadr?

The belief that the 27th night is definitely Laylat al-Qadr (The Night of Power) is incorrect. According to authentic Hadith, the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) was told the specific date of this night. However, due to a dispute between two of his companions, the knowledge was taken from him. He then instructed Muslims to search for Laylat al-Qadr in the last ten nights of Ramadan, especially on the odd-numbered nights. Therefore, it is more accurate to say that the 27th night is a strong possibility, but not a certainty.

A Common Concern

It's a regrettable trend that many people flock to the mosque at the beginning of Ramadan but the number of worshippers decreases significantly in the last ten days. This goes against the practice of the Prophet (PBUH), who would intensify his worship during this period. He would stay up all night, wake his family for prayer, and devote himself completely. This is the most blessed part of Ramadan, and our devotion should increase, not decrease.

It's also important to remember that performing the five daily prayers in congregation is a year-round obligation, not just for the month of Ramadan.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, November-2007, www.alkawsar.com

Is Suhur Essential for a Valid Fast?

A few days ago, on the last Friday of Ramadan, a CNG driver asked me a question while I was on my way to the Friday prayer. He said, "I had the intention to fast when I went to bed, but I didn't wake up for suhur (the pre-dawn meal). By the time I woke up, it was already morning. I then made my intention to fast. Is my fast valid?"

I've seen many people have this same doubt. They seem to believe that eating suhur is a prerequisite for a valid fast. However, this is not the case. The only thing essential for a valid fast is the niyyah (intention). Therefore, if someone misses their suhur for any reason—whether they overslept or simply chose not to eat—as long as they made the intention to fast, their fast is valid.

It's important to remember that eating suhur is a Sunnah and a source of great blessings. The Hadith strongly encourages eating suhur. One should not skip it without a valid reason. It's recommended to eat something, even if it's a small amount, to follow the Prophet's practice and reap the benefits of this blessed meal.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, November-2007, www.alkawsar.com

Not a Hadith

Can Speaking About Worldly Matters Destroy 40 Years of Worship?

The belief that speaking about worldly matters during the adhan, wudu, ziyarah, or inside a mosque can destroy 40 years of worship is a common misconception. This idea is completely baseless and has no foundation in Islamic teachings.

It's a serious sin to attribute such a statement to the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) as a Hadith, as it is a fabrication.

What Is the Correct Islamic Etiquette?

While the above-mentioned belief is false, it is still recommended to be mindful of your actions during these blessed moments:

During the adhan, wudu, and ziyarah: It is best to avoid unnecessary conversation and keep your mind focused on Allah. These are times for spiritual purity and remembrance.

In the mosque: Mosques are places of worship. It's best to refrain from idle chatter about worldly affairs to maintain the sanctity of the place.

However, if someone does speak about worldly matters out of necessity or even unintentionally, it will not invalidate their acts of worship. The idea that all of one's worship—let alone 40 years of it—would be destroyed is entirely false. It is important to avoid such superstitions and seek authentic Islamic knowledge.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, January 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Mistake

Does the Time for Iftar Start After the Adhan?

A while ago, I was with a friend who was fasting during the month of Shawwal. He broke his fast a little after the sun had set. Shortly after, the adhan for Maghrib was heard. Some people present exclaimed, "You broke your fast before the adhan!"

This incident highlights a common misconception that the time for iftar begins with the adhan. In reality, the time for iftar starts the moment the sun sets, which is also when the Maghrib prayer time begins. The adhan is simply a call to prayer that coincides with this moment.

In many places, people have the custom of waiting to hear the adhan before they break their fast. This practice has led some to mistakenly believe that the adhan itself marks the start of iftar time. This is incorrect. It is, in fact, against the Sunnah (the practice of the Prophet PBUH) to delay iftar without a valid reason. A person who is fasting should break their fast as soon as the sun has set.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, January 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Religious Ruling

Is it Necessary to Recite A'udhu Billah and Bismillah at the Beginning of the Sermon?

In some mosques, you may see the Imam loudly reciting "A'udhu billah" and "Bismillah" at the beginning of the Friday sermon (khutbah). It is likely that they do this with the intention of making the sermon more blessed. However, this practice is not correct.

While it's true that every important act should begin with some form of remembrance of Allah, it should be done in the way that Islam has prescribed for that specific act. For instance, prayer begins with the Takbiratul Ihram (Allahu Akbar), Hajj with the talbiyah ("Labbaik Allahumma Labbaik"), and the recitation of the Quran with "A'udhu billah" and "Bismillah."

The Sunnah (Prophetic tradition) for beginning a sermon is to start with "Alhamdulillah" (Praise be to Allah). The Prophet (PBUH) always began his sermons in this manner, and it has been the established practice from the time of the Companions until today. Therefore, starting the sermon with "A'udhu billah" and "Bismillah" is not the correct tradition.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, January 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Misconception

Is Hajj Merely a Global Conference?

While discussing the benefits of Hajj, Maulana Syed Abul Hasan Ali Nadwi (may Allah have mercy on him) wrote, "The Muslim community from all over the world gathers in Mecca for Hajj. This provides an opportunity for them to get to know each other, exchange views on various important matters, and foster unity. However, this is not the ultimate significance of Hajj, nor is it its greatest objective or benefit, even though some contemporary writers suggest otherwise. Similarly, Hajj is not a political conference, yet many thinkers, politicians, and Muslim leaders of our time present it this way."

If Hajj were intended to be a global conference, its rituals would be designed differently. The focus would be on stationary, long-term stays in one place to allow for extensive thought, study, discussion, and deliberation. The very nature of Hajj, however, is one of constant movement and continuous change of location, which is not conducive to the goals of a conference.

Furthermore, if Hajj were only a conference, its invitation would be limited to scholars, thinkers, politicians, and prominent leaders. But this is not the case. Hajj is a mandatory obligation for every Muslim, regardless of their status or education, provided they have the means to perform it. The Quran states, "Hajj to the House is a duty owed to Allah by all who can afford a way to it." (Surah Al-Imran: 97)

Therefore, while the social and political benefits are a byproduct of Hajj, they should not be considered its sole purpose or primary significance.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, January 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Misconception

Are the Three Jamarat in Mina Three Devils?

The belief that the three Jamarat pillars in Mina are three devils is incorrect. The word Jamarat is the plural of the Arabic word Jamrah, meaning "small pebbles." Throwing pebbles at these pillars is a ritual that reenacts the actions of Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham), who threw stones at the devil when he tried to stop him from fulfilling Allah's command to sacrifice his son.

The purpose of this ritual is to show defiance against Satan and to affirm one's obedience to Allah. It's important to understand that there are no devils at these locations, nor are any devils tied to the pillars. The act of throwing pebbles is an act of worship and a symbolic expression of our hatred for the devil.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, February 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Mistake

Are There Specific Duas for Each of the Seven Circuits of Tawaf?

The popular belief that there are specific, distinct prayers (duas) for each of the seven circuits of Tawaf is incorrect. This misconception leads many pilgrims to loudly recite these prayers from pamphlets, even if they cannot pronounce the words correctly. This practice is not an Islamic legal requirement and is not found in the Hadith.

The Correct Practice

There are no specific prayers for each circuit in the Sunnah. The only short, recommended Quranic prayer mentioned in the Hadith is one that is specifically recited in the area between the Rukn al-Yamani and the Hajar al-Aswad:

ربنا اتنا فى الدنيا حسنة وفى الاخرة حسنة وقنا عذاب النار

(Our Lord, give us in this world [that which is] good and in the Hereafter [that which is] good and protect us from the punishment of the Fire).

Aside from this, a pilgrim is free to make any valid prayer or heartfelt supplication to Allah, in any language, at any point during Tawaf.

This mistaken practice of reciting specific prayers in groups often causes difficulty for other pilgrims and disrupts their concentration. The correct approach is to focus on Allah with a sincere heart and make prayers individually and humbly.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, February 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Religious Ruling

Can a Person in Ihram Cover Their Feet with a Blanket or Cloth?

The idea that a person in the state of Ihram cannot cover their feet with a blanket or cloth is incorrect. This is a common misconception, as demonstrated by the experience of a man in Mina who was told by others that covering his feet was not permissible.

While in a state of Ihram, it is permissible to cover your feet with a cloth, blanket, or other similar items. What is forbidden is wearing certain types of footwear, specifically socks or other shoes that cover the entire foot. You are only allowed to wear sandals or slippers that leave your ankles and part of the foot exposed.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, March 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Baseless Custom

Is "Akhiri Chahar Shumba" a Day of Celebration?

The practice of celebrating "Akhiri Chahar Shumba"—the last Wednesday of the Islamic month of Safar—as a day of the Prophet Muhammad's (PBUH) recovery from illness is a baseless superstition. Some unreliable publications promote this day with special acts of worship, such as bathing, fasting, and giving charity, but this is entirely incorrect.

Why This Belief Is False

  • Incorrect Timing: According to accurate historical accounts, the Prophet's recovery from the illness caused by magic did not occur on the last Wednesday of Safar.

  • Lack of Evidence: There is no reliable Hadith or historical account that suggests the Prophet (PBUH) bathed to celebrate his recovery on this specific day, nor is there any evidence that the companions or early Muslims observed this day in any special way.

  • Contradiction in Practice: If celebrating the Prophet's recovery were a valid practice, he would have instructed his followers to do so for other instances when he recovered from a serious illness or injury in his life, which he did not.

  • Invalid Religious Ruling: A religious observance cannot be established based on unfounded historical interpretations or personal reasoning. It must have a basis in the Quran or the Sunnah.

  • Factual Inaccuracies: The books that promote this day contain factual errors. For example, the Prophet's passing occurred on a Monday, and the Wednesday before that was in the month of Rabi' al-Awwal, not Safar.

These baseless customs and rituals distract the Muslim community from the true Sunnah and lifestyle of the Prophet (PBUH). Muslims should stay away from such dangerous errors and follow only what is authentically established in the faith.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, March 2008, www.alkawsar.com

Is This a Hadith?

Giving Salam Gives 90 Rewards, and Replying Gives 10

The popular saying that giving a greeting of salam earns 90 rewards while replying earns 10 is not an authentic Hadith. This statement is not found in the well-known, reliable collections of prophetic traditions.

Instead, a correct Hadith states the following:

  • Saying "As-salamu alaikum" earns 10 rewards.

  • Adding "wa rahmatullah" brings the total to 20 rewards.

  • Adding "wa barakatuh" to complete the greeting earns a full 30 rewards.

This Hadith is found in authoritative collections such as Sunan Abi Dawud and Jami' al-Tirmidhi. Therefore, it is important to promote this authentic tradition instead of the fabricated saying.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, May 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Baseless Custom

Is "Fatiha-e-Yazdaham" Supported by Islamic Law?

The custom of observing "Fatiha-e-Yazdaham" on the 11th of the Islamic month of Rabi' al-Thani is a baseless practice. Its followers believe this date marks the passing of the renowned scholar and saint, Sheikh Abdul Qadir Jilani (may Allah have mercy on him).

However, this custom has no basis in Islam. Islam does not prescribe celebrating birthdays or death anniversaries. Furthermore, neither Sheikh Jilani himself nor his followers ever observed such an event.

The Misinformation Behind the Practice

Interestingly, even the date of this celebration is incorrect. Historical sources confirm that Sheikh Jilani passed away on the 8th, 9th, or 10th of Rabi' al-Thani, not the 11th.

Adding to the problem, some speakers at these gatherings promote false claims. They misname Sheikh Jilani's teacher and even assert that he had the power to "bring the dead back to life." Such a claim is a form of Shirk (associating partners with Allah), as the power over life and death belongs solely to Allah.

Therefore, this custom is not only a superstition but also a platform for promoting polytheism and Bid'ah (religious innovations).

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, May 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Thought

Is There No Culture in Islam?

Many people, including some who are educated in the English language and lack a proper foundational knowledge of Islam, mistakenly believe that Islam is only a collection of doctrines and rules. They hold the false notion that Islam provides no guidelines for culture or civilization.

This idea is completely wrong. Islam is a complete way of life, and it includes a full and perfect culture or tahzib (civilization). Islam does not separate its religious principles from its cultural framework.

The primary sources of Islamic law—the Quran and the Sunnah—contain extensive principles and rulings related to Islamic culture and civilization. Just as other aspects of Islamic law have been compiled from these sources, so too have the rules of Islamic culture been compiled into a comprehensive framework. The authentic Islamic culture is one that transcends race, language, ethnicity, or geographical location, uniting all Muslims under a single, shared identity.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, May 2008, www.alkawsar.com

Is This a Hadith?

"As-Salatu Mi'rajul Mu'minin" (Prayer is the Mi'raj of the Believers)

This phrase, "Prayer is the Mi'raj (ascension) of the believers," is a popular saying, and some people mistakenly believe it is a Hadith (a saying of the Prophet Muhammad). However, this statement is not found in the well-known and authentic collections of Hadith.

While it is not a direct prophetic saying, its meaning is derived from other, authentic Hadiths. Therefore, it should be regarded as a respected saying, not as a Hadith.

Here are some authentic Hadiths that convey a similar meaning and can be quoted instead:

"When a believer stands for prayer, he is in intimate conversation with his Lord." (Sahih Bukhari, Hadith 413)

"When any one of you stands in prayer, he is conversing with Allah as long as he remains in his place of prayer." (Sahih Bukhari, Hadith 426)

These Hadiths accurately describe the deep spiritual connection a believer experiences during prayer, which is the true essence of the saying.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, August 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Grave Misunderstanding

Is "Sufism" the True Islam?

Islam is not just a collection of beliefs and acts of worship; it's a complete way of life. This includes social relations, ethics, law, and governance. In the third century, the principles of self-purification and moral reform were formalized under the name Tasawwuf. However, Tasawwuf is only a part of Islamic law (Shari'ah), not the entirety of it. A Muslim must believe in and submit to all of Islam's principles, not just a select few.

Over time, certain heretical and opportunistic groups created a corrupted version of Tasawwuf, based on personal desires and a lack of moral discipline. They deceptively used the name of genuine Tasawwuf to legitimize their actions.

Modern "Sufism" vs. True Tasawwuf

In our time, this corrupted version of Tasawwuf has evolved into what is often called "Sufism," which is promoted by secular-minded individuals. They claim that this "Sufism" is the true Islam, while denying the importance of the Shari'ah. This is a tactic to reject the completeness of Islam.

True Tasawwuf is an integral part of the Shari'ah, and its adherents uphold all of Islam's commandments, including enjoining good, forbidding evil, jihad, and governing with justice. The "Sufism" promoted by Western or secular thinkers has no connection to authentic Islamic Tasawwuf. It is, in fact, a cunning and dangerous way to reject the true nature of Islam.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, August 2008, www.alkawsar.com

Is This a Hadith?

Are There 244,000 Prophets?

The total number of prophets from the first Prophet, Adam (PBUH), to the last, Muhammad (PBUH), is not a compulsory piece of knowledge for Muslims. While a popular, yet unreliable, saying mentions the number 224,000, this figure is not found in any authentic Hadith.

According to the scholar Mullah Ali Qari (may Allah have mercy on him), in his book Iqdul Faraid fi Takhriji Ahadith Sharhil Aqaaid, the Hadith scholar Hafiz Jalali (may Allah have mercy on him) stated, "I have not found this narration."

Therefore, this number is not an authentic Hadith but rather a common saying without a reliable source.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, September 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Misconception

Is It Sunnah to Buy All New Things for Eid?

The idea that you must wear new clothes and buy new things for Eid is a popular misconception. The correct Islamic practice is simply to wear the best and cleanest clothes you already have. Social custom has distorted this, leading people to believe that buying new clothes, shoes, socks, and even furniture is a Sunnah (prophetic practice).

This belief is incorrect. The only Sunnah is to take a full bath, be clean, and wear your nicest clothes on Eid. You don't have to buy anything new.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, September 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Popular Mistake

"Say It This Way, Not That Way"

The phrase, "Islam is a complete system of life," is a popular saying. However, it is not an entirely accurate way to describe Islam. While it aims to convey an important truth, it can give the mistaken impression that Islam is merely a social or revolutionary system. This oversimplifies the true essence of Islam.

The correct way to define Islam is to call it a complete Din (religion or way of life). One of its unique characteristics is that it contains a complete system of life. This distinction is important because it clarifies that Islam is not just a set of rules or a system; rather, it provides perfect guidance and solutions for all aspects of human life.

Therefore, instead of saying, "Islam is a complete system of life," it is more precise and comprehensive to say, "Islam contains a complete system of life." This phrasing better captures the true and full identity of Islam.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, September 2008, www.alkawsar.com

"The Food of the Deceased Kills the Hearts"

This statement is not a Hadith; it is a popular saying among some religious scholars. While it is not a direct prophetic tradition, the meaning behind it points to several important Islamic principles regarding mourning and charity.

The Reasons Behind the Saying

The saying means that food prepared for the deceased can be spiritually barren or "deadly" to the heart. This is because:

Food for Sorrow: Feasts are meant for joyous occasions, not for times of mourning and grief. Food prepared for a funeral or in the days after can lack spiritual blessing.

Incorrect Method: The act of feeding people in exchange for them reciting the Quran or performing other acts of worship for the deceased is not permissible in Islam.

However, giving food to the poor and needy with the intention of earning reward for the deceased (Isal-e-Sawab) is a very virtuous act. This should be done correctly, with the following conditions:

The food must be bought with halal earnings.

It must come from one's own wealth, not from inherited property that has not yet been distributed.

It should not be performed on specific, customary days like the 3rd, 10th, or 40th day after death, as this practice has no basis in the Sunnah.

There should be no reciprocal arrangement where food is given in exchange for religious rituals.

It's always best for each individual to perform acts of charity, such as giving money or food, praying nawafil (supererogatory prayers), or making sincere dua for the forgiveness and salvation of the deceased.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, October 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Misconception

Is It Necessary for the Imam to "Gift" the Reward of a Qur'an Recitation?

In many mosques, especially in rural areas, people often ask the Imam to "gift" the reward of a complete Qur'an recitation (khatm) to a deceased person. This practice gives the impression that it is essential for an Imam or a pious person to perform this ritual for the khatm to be valid.

This belief is incorrect. Completing the recitation of the Qur'an is a great act of worship, and it is a personal one. It is not necessary to inform others about it, as it is a private act between a person and Allah.

If someone wishes to dedicate the reward of their recitation to a deceased person, they do not need an intermediary. All they have to do is make the intention in their heart, saying, "O Allah, please convey the reward of this recitation to the deeds of all Muslim deceased, or to a specific person." The reward is not something that needs to be "gifted" by someone else; simply making the intention to transfer it is enough.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, October 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Religious Ruling

Does One Have Permission to Break a Fast While Traveling?

While on a religious journey (safar), a person has permission to not fast, but they must make up for those missed fasts later. However, it is better to fast during a journey to avoid missing the blessings of Ramadan.

Some people mistakenly phrase this ruling by saying, "It is permissible to break a fast while traveling." This wording is incorrect because it implies that one can intentionally break a fast after starting it, which is not allowed. The correct understanding is that a traveler has the permission to not start the fast in the first place, not to break it once it has begun.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, October 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Belief

Are There No Rules When You Have an Excuse?

It's a common misconception that when a person is in a state of hardship or has a valid excuse (udhr), they are no longer bound by Islamic law. Some people think that in such situations, they can do whatever they want because "there are no rules when you have an excuse."

This idea is completely wrong. Islam is a comprehensive religion, and its teachings apply to all circumstances. The Shari'ah (Islamic law) provides special accommodations, known as rukhas (dispensations), for those who are sick or face hardship. These rulings are discussed in detail in Islamic jurisprudence books.

A Muslim's duty is to determine whether their situation is a valid excuse in the eyes of the Shari'ah. If it is, they should learn the specific rulings that apply to them and act accordingly, rather than relying on guesswork or using the excuse as a pretext to abandon their religious obligations. The rules may change, but they are never completely abandoned.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, October 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Misconception

Are the Jamarat in Mina Monuments or Sculptures?

The claim that the Jamarat pillars in Mina and the pillar on Jabal al-Rahmah in Arafat are sculptures is completely false. People who make this claim often do so to justify their own preference for sculptures and to spread the mistaken belief that such things are permissible in Islam.

The Reality of the Jamarat and Arafat Pillars

The Jamarat Pillars in Mina: These are not sculptures or monuments. They are simply markers that identify the exact locations where Prophet Ibrahim (Abraham) threw stones to repel Satan. These pillars have no images of any living beings or objects on them and are intended to be a symbol of the humiliation of Satan.

The Pillar on Jabal al-Rahmah in Arafat: There is no specific, authenticated location in Arafat where Prophet Adam and Eve met. The small white pillar on top of Jabal al-Rahmah has no images. It was erected only to mark Jabal al-Rahmah (the Mountain of Mercy), where the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) delivered his farewell sermon during his last pilgrimage.

Such false claims are a deliberate attempt to cause confusion about the sacred symbols of Islam.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, November 2008, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Religious Ruling

Is It Wrong to Leave the Miqat Boundary While in Ihram?

The belief that it is impermissible to leave the boundary of the Miqat after entering a state of Ihram (the sacred state for Hajj or Umrah) is a common misconception. This idea is incorrect; leaving the Miqat boundary does not invalidate one's state of Ihram.

For example, a person performing Hajj al-Ifrad or Hajj al-Qiran may have entered Makkah and completed their initial Tawaf. If they decide to visit the Prophet's Mosque in Madinah before the main days of Hajj, there is nothing wrong with this.

While it is generally recommended to remain in the vicinity of the Holy sites, there is no prohibition against leaving the sacred boundaries if there is a need to do so.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, November 2008, www.alkawsar.com

Is This a Hadith?

Will the Day of Judgment Happen on Ashura?

When discussing the importance of Ashura (the 10th day of Muharram), some people say, "It has been narrated in a Hadith that the Day of Judgment will occur on this day."

This statement is not correct. According to the consensus of Hadith scholars, any narration claiming that the Day of Judgment will take place on Ashura is baseless and fabricated.

Scholars like Allama Abul Faraj ibn al-Jawzi have explicitly stated that this narration is "undoubtedly a fabricated report." Other scholars, including Hafiz Suyuti and Allama ibn al-Arraq, agreed with this ruling.

However, it is confirmed in authentic Hadiths that the Day of Judgment will occur on a Friday.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, January 2009, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Misconception

Is One Sin in the Haram Worth a Hundred Thousand Sins?

While inside the Haram (the sacred precinct of Makkah), one person was heard telling another, "One sin in the Haram is equal to a hundred thousand sins. We should be mindful of this."

This idea is incorrect. It is a proven fact from authentic Hadith that performing one unit of prayer (rak'ah) inside the Masjid al-Haram (the Ka'bah) is equivalent to a hundred thousand rak'ahs in a normal mosque. However, there is no authentic Hadith that confirms this multiplied reward for prayers outside of the mosque but still within the Haram boundaries.

Furthermore, it is a great mistake to apply this principle to sins. Allah is the Most Merciful and Most Compassionate; He multiplies the rewards for good deeds—giving at least ten times more, and for some acts like prayer in the Haram, even a hundred thousand times more. But for sins, Allah's rule is that one sin is recorded as just one sin. Of course, committing a sin in the Haram is more serious because it shows a lack of respect for the sanctity of the place, but this does not mean the sin is multiplied a hundred thousand times.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, January 2009, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Practice

A common mistake made by many pilgrims during the Hajj season is to join the congregational prayer from a great distance, even across a street, outside the Masjid al-Haram. They do this hoping to gain the multiplied reward of a hundred thousand prayers. This is a mistaken practice.

Conditions for a Valid Prayer Behind an Imam

For a prayer to be valid when praying outside the mosque, the rows of worshippers must be connected. If there is a break in the rows—such as a street, a river, or a large open space—the prayer is not valid.

Many people stand so far away that they cannot even hear the Imam's voice directly but instead rely on the sound from a nearby mosque. This also invalidates the prayer because of the significant gap.

The correct approach is:

  • To move forward and fill the gap to connect with the row in front.

  • If that is not possible, to join the congregation of a closer mosque.

  • To form your own small congregation if there are other people nearby in a similar situation.

By praying incorrectly, a person will not receive the reward they are seeking, as the prayer itself is not considered valid.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, January 2009, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Misconception

Do Women Not Need to Observe Hijab During Hajj?

Some people mistakenly believe that women are not required to observe hijab (modest dress, including a face covering in some interpretations) during Hajj. This is completely false. It is an essential obligation for women to observe hijab in the presence of non-mahram men, even while in a state of Ihram.

While women are forbidden from wearing a face-covering veil that touches their skin, this does not mean they should deliberately expose their face to men who are not immediate family.

As recorded in Sunan Abi Dawud, Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) said, "We were with the Messenger of Allah (PBUH) in the state of Ihram. When a man passed by us, we would pull our cloaks down over our faces, and when he had passed, we would uncover them."

Furthermore, the rule about not covering the face only applies for a few days during the Hajj or Umrah rituals. For the rest of the pilgrimage, especially during the visit to Madinah, there is no excuse for not observing full hijab.

Exposing one's face and treating all non-mahram men as if they are family is a sign of ignorance and only leads to sin. To receive the full blessings of this blessed journey, it is essential to remain mindful and careful about all aspects of Islamic law.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, January 2009, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Misconception

Is 786 a Substitute for "Bismillah"?

In situations where writing or saying "Bismillahir Rahmanir Rahim" (In the Name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful) is a recommended practice, some people use the number 786 instead. This number is based on the Abjad system, where each letter has a numerical value, and the sum of the letters in "Bismillahir Rahmanir Rahim" adds up to 786.

The belief that this number can serve as a substitute for saying or writing "Bismillah" is completely mistaken. While the number might be used as a symbol for "Bismillah" if it is written after a person has verbally recited the full phrase, it is wrong to consider it a direct replacement.

Abandoning a well-established practice (Sunnah) that has been followed by scholars and pious Muslims throughout history in favor of a numerical abbreviation is not an acceptable practice in Islam.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, February 2009, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Religious Ruling

Is Growing a Beard an Optional Sunnah?

The beard is a sign of a Muslim's identity. Growing the beard and trimming the mustache is a practice from the Din al-Tawhid (the religion of monotheism) that was followed by all prophets. It is an obligation (wajib) to grow one's beard to at least a fistful and is impermissible to trim it shorter than that or to shave it entirely. Since this was the practice of all the prophets, it is also referred to as a Sunnah.

This has led to the misconception that growing a beard is like other optional Sunnahs—something good to do, but not sinful to omit. This is a completely false idea. The beard is not an optional Sunnah; it is a Sunnah Wajiba, meaning it is more important than a Sunnah Muakkadah (confirmed Sunnah) and a person who neglects it is committing a sin.

Shaving the beard or trimming it shorter than a fistful is a constant, visible sin that is impossible to hide. Furthermore, this act often stems from a dislike for the Sunnah and an attraction to un-Islamic fashion, which can even put one's faith in a precarious position.

A Mistaken Belief

Do Sheikh Abdul Qadir Jilani or Moinuddin Chishti Have Their Own "Beautiful Names"?

Allah has many beautiful names, known as Al-Asmaul Husna. These names can only be known through divine revelation. A Hadith states that whoever memorizes 99 of Allah's names will enter Paradise.

The Correct vs. Incorrect Practices

What is permissible:

  • Only invoke and pray to Allah using His names.

  • Chant only the names of Allah and seek help exclusively from Him, as this is His sole right.

What is not permissible (Shirk and Bid'ah):

  • Chanting or seeking help from anyone other than Allah.

  • Reciting litanies (wazifas) with a spiritual guide's (pir's) name. Some people even invent names for their guides, some of which are meaningless or promote polytheism.

  • Reciting lists of names like the "99 names" of Khwaja Moinuddin Chishti (may Allah have mercy on him). Ignorant people create these lists and encourage others to chant them as an act of worship.

These are acts of ignorance and Shirk. It's a tragedy that some who claim to be followers of Khwaja Moinuddin Chishti, a champion of Tawhid (monotheism) who guided countless people away from Shirk, have fallen into these misguided practices themselves.

Not a Hadith:

الشيخ في قومه كالنبي في أمته

The Sheikh in his people is like a Prophet in his nation.

This saying is not an authentic Hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH); it is a statement attributed to some Sufi masters. The narrators who claimed it to be a Hadith are considered unreliable.

Why the Saying is Problematic

Even as a saying, it shouldn't be used because it can lead people to dangerous misunderstandings. It might cause an ignorant person to believe that their spiritual guide (Sheikh or Pir) is infallible like a prophet or that their words are a source of Islamic law (Shari'ah). This is a form of ghulu (exaggeration or extremism) and a grave deviation from correct Islamic belief.

Only a prophet is divinely protected from sin and error, and his words and actions are a direct source of law. A Sheikh is a human being; his guidance is only accepted if it is in strict accordance with the Sunnah (the practice of the Prophet PBUH) and the Shari'ah.

While seeking the company of pious and knowledgeable spiritual guides is a praiseworthy practice, likening them to prophets is an act of exaggeration that should be avoided.

A Sahih Hadith clarifies the true status of scholars and spiritual guides:

"The scholars are the heirs of the Prophets. The Prophets did not leave behind dinars or dirhams, but they left behind knowledge. Whoever takes it has taken a great share." (Sunan Abi Dawud, Hadith 3636)

This Hadith shows that scholars inherit the knowledge of the prophets, not their status, infallibility, or divine authority.

A Common Misconception

Is "Allahumma Inna Nasta'inuka..." the Only Du'a al-Qunut?

The belief that the Du'a al-Qunut for the Witr prayer must be the specific supplication that begins with "Allahumma Inna Nasta'inuka..." is incorrect. While this prayer is commonly recited, it is not the only valid one.

In the third rak'ah of the Witr prayer, it is a necessary act to recite a qunut (supplication). There are several supplications that can be used, including "Allahummah dini fiiman hadait..." Any ma'thur (narrated from the Prophet PBUH) or masnun (based on the Prophet's practice) supplication from the Quran or Hadith can fulfill this obligation.

The misconception that only one specific du'a is acceptable is false. The goal is to perform a sincere supplication, and any of the valid forms will suffice.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, March 2009, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Misconception

Is Surah Al-Fatiha Not Part of Qira'ah?

Some people wrongly believe that Qira'ah, the recitation of the Quran during prayer, refers only to the verses recited after Surah Al-Fatiha. This leads to the misconception that it's unnecessary for followers to remain silent when the Imam is reciting Surah Al-Fatiha. This belief is entirely mistaken, as Surah Al-Fatiha is an essential part of Qira'ah in the terminology of the Quran and Hadith.

The Hadith states:

"When the Imam recites, listen quietly." (Sahih Muslim, Hadith 404)

In this context, "recites" refers to the entire Quranic recitation of the Imam, including Surah Al-Fatiha. Therefore, it is a necessary part of prayer for followers to remain silent during the Imam's full recitation.

Some extremists have even gone so far as to claim that Surah Al-Fatiha is not part of the Quran. This is a grave error and contradicts the clear teachings of the Quran itself.

A Fabricated Story

Did Abu Bakr Siddiq (RA) Organize Mawlid Celebrations?

The story that Abu Bakr Siddiq (may Allah be pleased with him) used to hold annual Mawlid (Prophet's birthday) celebrations and even once saw the Prophet in a dream who instructed him to use dates for the celebration is a fabricated and baseless tale. It is not found in any authentic Hadith or reliable book of prophetic traditions.

Why the Story Is False

Historical Inaccuracy: The Mawlid celebration as a formal event started centuries after the time of the Prophet (PBUH) and the Rightly Guided Caliphs. The practice was adopted from customs of other religions and was not known during their era.

Emphasis on Food: The very nature of this story—focusing on the lack of funds and the need for food (dates) to perform the ritual—highlights the emphasis on feasts and celebrations, which is a hallmark of this innovated practice.

Misunderstanding of the Prophet's Life: The true way to remember the Prophet (PBUH) is to study his life (Sirah) and follow his teachings. This can be done at any time and in any place and does not require a formal gathering or spending money. The absence of funds should never be a reason to abandon a righteous act.

Authentic love for the Prophet (PBUH) is shown through sincere devotion and following his Sunnah, not through baseless customs and fabricated stories.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, April 2009 www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Practice:

Not Praying Two Rak'ahs When There Isn't Time for Four

Some people mistakenly believe that if they don't have enough time to pray four rak'ahs (units of prayer) before the congregational prayer, they should skip praying altogether. This is often seen with the pre-prayer Sunnahs for Zuhr, 'Asr, and 'Isha, which are four rak'ahs.

This is a wrong practice. A Hadith from the Prophet (PBUH) says, "When one of you enters the mosque, he should not sit down until he has prayed two rak'ahs" (Sahih Bukhari, Hadith 444). This prayer is called Tahiyyatul Masjid (the greeting of the mosque). It is a highly recommended Sunnah to perform this two-rak'ah prayer whenever one enters a mosque, except in specific situations.

You can still pray these two rak'ahs even if there isn't enough time to perform the full four-rak'ah Sunnahs. The pre-prayer Sunnahs for 'Asr and 'Isha are flexible; they can be prayed as either two or four rak'ahs. Therefore, it is a significant mistake to sit down and miss out on the opportunity to perform a valid prayer simply because you can't complete the full four units.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, April 2009 www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Religious Ruling

Some people mistakenly believe it's disliked (makrooh) to engage in any form of worship—like reciting the Quran (tilawah), making supplications (dua), or remembering Allah (dhikr)—during the three times when prayer is forbidden.

This is not correct. The prohibition is specifically for performing prayers (salat). It is completely permissible and even encouraged to perform other acts of worship, such as dhikr, tilawah, and making dua, during those times. The dislike applies only to starting or performing a prayer.

Another Misconception

Was Khawaja Abdullah the Eldest of His Brothers?

In biographies of the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) written in Urdu or Bengali, it is often mentioned that the Prophet had nine uncles. Some people mistakenly assume from this that Khawaja Abdullah, the Prophet's father, was the eldest among Abdul Muttalib's sons.

A Common Historical Mistake

Was Abu Jahl the Prophet's Uncle?

Some people mistakenly believe that Abu Jahl, a leader of the polytheists in Makkah, was an uncle of the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH), similar to Abu Lahab. This is incorrect. While both were from the Quraysh tribe, they were not related in the same way.

Abu Lahab was the brother of Khawaja Abdullah, the Prophet's father, and was therefore the Prophet's paternal uncle.

Abu Jahl, however, was not from the same lineage. His full name and lineage are: "Abu Jahl 'Amr ibn Hisham ibn Mughira ibn 'Abdullah ibn 'Umar ibn Makhzum." He was a member of a different clan within the Quraysh tribe.

A Baseless Custom or Narration

Is It Discouraged to Eat After Asr?

It is a baseless idea to believe that eating anything between the 'Asr and Maghrib prayers is a bad or prohibited practice. This belief is entirely unfounded.

In Islam, eating and drinking are only forbidden during fasting hours. Outside of that, there is no prohibition. Of course, a person may choose to avoid eating at certain times for personal health reasons or a doctor's advice, but this is a private matter.

There is no basis in Islamic law for the notion that refraining from eating at this specific time is a virtuous or recommended act. Following such a self-imposed, baseless custom is discouraged. While it's fine for someone to not eat if they don't feel the need to, turning this personal habit into a religious rule is not permissible.

The Ascent of the Prophet (Miraj)

The text discusses some common misunderstandings and careless approaches to talking about the Miraj (the Prophet's night journey and ascension to the heavens).

Common Mistakes

  1. Trying to Explain the Miraj with Science: It is pointless to use science to try and prove the possibility of the Miraj. This miraculous journey wasn't accomplished by human power; it was made possible by the infinite power of Allah, the Creator of the universe. For a believer, there should be no doubt about this event, as it is a manifestation of divine power, not a scientific phenomenon.

  2. Believing Unverified Narrations: It's a significant mistake to accept and narrate any story about the Miraj without verifying its authenticity. One should only rely on information found in reliable sources like Sahih Bukhari and Sahih Muslim.

  3. Describing Allah as Being in a Place: It is extremely dangerous to narrate the Miraj in a way that implies Allah resides in a specific location, such as the Arsh (Throne). This contradicts the fundamental Islamic belief that Allah is transcendent and exists beyond time and space, both of which are His creations.

To avoid these errors, the Miraj should be understood and discussed solely based on the clear teachings of the Quran and Sahih Hadith.

A Common Mistake: "Du'a of Ibrahim" Is Not a Hadith

In some editions of Munajat-e-Maqbul (a book of prayers compiled by Maulana Ashraf Ali Thanvi), a supplication titled "Du'a of Ibrahim" is printed at the end. It is also sometimes recommended to recite it every Friday morning and evening.

This prayer has no connection to the Prophet Ibrahim (PBUH) and is not part of the original Munajat-e-Maqbul collection. It was added by a publisher for reasons that are unknown. A Mistaken Ruling

Does a Widow Forfeit Her Inheritance Upon Remarrying?

The belief that a widow loses her right to her deceased husband's inheritance if she remarries is completely false and based on ignorance.

According to Islamic law, a wife becomes an immediate heir to her husband's property at the moment of his death, as long as she is alive at that time. Her right to that inheritance is not affected by any subsequent marriage. Depriving a widow of her rightful inheritance for this reason is a major sin and a clear violation of the Shari'ah.

Unfortunately, this wrong belief is an extension of the pre-Islamic custom of not allowing widows to remarry. This is a practice from the time of ignorance (jahiliyyah) that Islam does not approve of.

Those who are responsible for the welfare of a widow have a duty to help her remarry if there is no genuine reason preventing it (social pressure is not a valid reason). By doing so, they not only fulfill a significant responsibility but also receive the reward for reviving a neglected Sunnah.

A Mistaken Custom

Is Greeting and Shaking Hands After a Wedding Proposal a Sunnah?

It's a clear teaching of Islam that one should greet people with salam and a handshake (musafaha) upon meeting them. However, a common custom has emerged in some wedding ceremonies where the groom, after the marriage contract (ijab-qubul) is finalized, stands up and greets everyone with salam and musafaha, often prompted by an elder.

This practice is not a Sunnah. The groom has already been present in the gathering and would have greeted the people upon his arrival. This post-ceremony greeting is just another custom, not a required or even logical act.

The actual Sunnah after the ijab-qubul is to make a special prayer for the newlywed couple. A well-known du'a from a Hadith is:

"May Allah bless you and shower His blessings upon you and may He unite you both in goodness." (Jami' at-Tirmidhi, Hadith 1091).

The focus should be on making this prayer, not on adopting extra-religious customs.

An Unjust Practice

Incomplete or Incorrect Recitation and Writing of "Bismillah" and "Durud"

A Weakness in Thought

This text discusses two different reasons for celebrating the end of Ramadan.

A true believer is joyous at the end of Ramadan because Allah has blessed them with the opportunity to fast, pray Tarawih and Tahajjud, and engage in other acts of worship. Their heart is filled with hope for Allah's mercy, forgiveness, and salvation from hellfire. Their joy is an expression of gratitude to Allah for allowing them to complete this blessed month and earn His immense rewards.

This kind of attitude is usually found among those who did not fast properly or neglected their religious duties. For them, Ramadan truly was a month of loss, as they missed out on its immense blessings.

A Common Misconception

Confusing the Ihram Garment with the State of Ihram

The belief that the Ihram garment itself is the state of Ihram is a widespread misunderstanding. This can lead to serious errors during Hajj or Umrah.

The State of Ihram vs. The Garment

  • The state of Ihram is an inner spiritual state that begins when a person makes the specific intention (niyah) for Hajj or Umrah and recites the Talbiyah. The two white, seamless sheets worn by men are simply the prescribed clothing for this state, not the state itself. Putting on the garments alone, without the intention and Talbiyah, does not make a person a muhrim (one in the state of Ihram).

  • Similarly, if the Ihram garments become dirty, they can be changed or washed without invalidating the Ihram. The purity of the garments is separate from the spiritual state.

What to Do in an Emergency

If a pilgrim accidentally leaves their Ihram garments in their luggage and cannot access them before crossing the Miqat (the boundary for entering Ihram), they don't need to panic. The correct procedure is to make the intention and recite the Talbiyah while still in their regular clothes. When they reach their luggage in Jeddah, they should immediately change into the proper Ihram garments. However, since they wore forbidden stitched clothing in the state of Ihram, they are required to pay a kaffarah (an expiatory donation).

Because of this misconception, many pilgrims mistakenly cross the Miqat without entering Ihram, which is a major sin and requires them to sacrifice an animal (dam) as an atonement. It is essential to understand these rules clearly to ensure a valid Hajj or Umrah.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, November 2009, www.alkawsar.com

A Common Misconception

Is the Haram the Same as the Masjid al-Haram?

The belief that the terms Haram and Masjid al-Haram refer to the same place is a common misconception. The two are distinct.

The Difference Between the Two

  • Masjid al-Haram: This is the specific mosque that surrounds the Kaaba. It is the holiest mosque in Islam, where the reward for a single prayer is multiplied to a hundred thousand. Its boundaries are clearly visible and well-defined.

  • Haram: This is a much larger, sacred area that encompasses the entire city of Makkah and its surroundings. It has special rules and sanctity. Its boundaries extend to Arafat in the east, Hudaibiyah (Shumaissi) in the west, Ji'rana in the north, and Shubaika in the south.

The Two Misconceptions

People often shorten "Masjid al-Haram" to "Haram," which has led to two main false beliefs:

  • Some think that "Haram" is just another name for the mosque.

  • Others believe that the entire Haram area is as sacred as the mosque and that all prayers performed within its boundaries receive the same multiplied reward.

The Correct Understanding

The Masjid al-Haram is just the name of the mosque itself. The Haram is the broader, sacred region that includes the mosque, along with other holy sites like Safa, Marwa, Mina, and Muzdalifah.

While some scholars hold the opinion that acts of worship throughout the entire Haram region carry a multiplied reward, there is no strong evidence to support this claim. Even if that were the case, the unique spiritual blessings of praying in congregation inside the Masjid al-Haram, being close to the Kaaba, and joining a massive gathering of believers cannot be found anywhere else. Therefore, a person should not miss the opportunity to pray in the Masjid al-Haram's congregation for any reason.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, November 2009, www.alkawsar.com

A Fabricated Hadith

"Seek Knowledge, Even in China"

The phrase, "Seek knowledge, even in China," is widely quoted, but it is not an authentic Hadith from the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH). Although the statement's message is correct and aligns with Islamic principles—encouraging believers to travel far and wide to acquire both religious and worldly knowledge—the phrase itself is not from a reliable source.

The chain of narration for this saying includes a narrator named Abu 'Atibah Tarif ibn Sulayman, who has been accused by Hadith scholars of fabricating narrations and is considered "matruk" (abandoned). Scholars of rijal (the study of narrators) have documented his unreliability.

While the spirit of the saying is valid, it is crucial to avoid attributing fabricated statements to the Prophet (PBUH). The true status of this statement is a saying whose meaning is sound, but its source is not prophetic.

A Common Misconception

The Obligation of Praying 40 Times in Masjid an-Nabawi

Praying in a congregation is highly encouraged in Islam, and the reward is significantly multiplied in Masjid an-Nabawi (the Prophet's Mosque) in Madinah. Many pilgrims visit Madinah to pray there and visit the Prophet's tomb, which is a highly praiseworthy act.

The Misunderstanding of the "Eight-Day Stay"

Some people believe it's mandatory to stay in Madinah for at least eight days to pray a total of 40 prayers in the Prophet's Mosque. This belief is based on a weak Hadith which says that whoever prays 40 consecutive prayers in the mosque will be granted protection from hellfire and hypocrisy. However, a sounder Hadith states this virtue can be achieved by praying 40 consecutive prayers in any mosque.

The Correct Perspective

  • There is no religious obligation to stay in Madinah for eight days. While it's good to stay for this duration if it's convenient, it should not be treated as a strict requirement that causes difficulty or stress.

  • Although weak Hadiths can be used to promote good deeds, they are not a basis for establishing religious laws or specific timeframes.

  • The essential point is to make every effort to pray in the congregation at both the Masjid al-Haram in Makkah and the Masjid an-Nabawi in Madinah for as long as you are able to.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, January 2010, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Religious Ruling

Is It Forbidden for a Child to Drink His Sister's Milk?

It's a common misconception that a child is forbidden from drinking milk from his sister. This belief is entirely incorrect and is considered a prevalent mistake.

There are no restrictions on a child drinking milk from any woman, regardless of whether she is a mahram (a person with whom marriage is forbidden, such as a mother or sister) or a ghayr mahram (a person with whom marriage is permissible). The key point is that the milk is given within the specified period of breastfeeding.

While it is permissible, it is still recommended to choose a righteous and pious woman as a wet-nurse if possible, as it is believed that the milk can have a minor influence on a child's character. However, there is absolutely no religious prohibition against a sister breastfeeding her sibling.

A Surprising Slander:

Is One Obligated to Say "In the Fire of Hell" for a Deceased Non-Believer?

A Mistaken Notion

Is Spiritual Self-Improvement Exclusively for Initiated Disciples?

The belief that **spiritual self-improvement (islah-e-nafs) and the recitation of litanies (dhikr and wazifa) are only for those who have taken a pledge of allegiance (bay'ah) to a spiritual guide (pir) is a widespread and dangerous misconception.

The Original Pledge: By reciting the Kalima (the Islamic creed), every Muslim has, in essence, already made a pledge to Allah. The conventional bay'ah is simply a renewal of this fundamental commitment. Therefore, every Muslim is a spiritual traveler (salik) striving to purify their soul.

The Goal of Spiritual Practice: This kind of spiritual work is meant to protect a person from the deception of the lower self (nafs) and Satan. It's a personal journey that every believer must undertake to elevate their spiritual status.

Not a Hadith

"The world is given to serve those who serve Me"

The widely quoted saying, "Allah revealed to the world (dunya): 'Serve the one who serves Me, and tire the one who serves you,'" is not an authentic Hadith from the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH). Although its message encourages piety and detachment from worldly pursuits, it is a fabricated narration.

Intention: Making the intention in your heart.

Takbirat al-Ihram: Clearly pronouncing "Allahu Akbar."

The author recounts an incident where he was leading a prayer and received a lukmah. Afterward, some congregants claimed that since he took the correction, he was required to perform sajda al-sahw. They insisted that because he didn't, the prayer was invalid and needed to be repeated.

The Correct Ruling

The author clarifies that this is an incorrect understanding of Islamic jurisprudence. Sajda al-sahw is only required for errors in the wajib (obligatory) parts of the prayer. It has no connection to errors in recitation. If a person makes a mistake in recitation that is severe enough to invalidate the prayer, sajda al-sahw will not fix it; the prayer must be repeated entirely. However, if the error is minor, or if the Imam corrects a major error with the help of a lukmah and continues the prayer correctly, the prayer remains valid. In this case, neither repeating the prayer nor performing sajda al-sahw is necessary.

The author notes that this misconception likely stems from a lack of knowledge among the general public and expresses his intention to write more on the rulings of sajda al-sahw in a future article.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, March 2012, www.alkawsar.com

A Grave Religious Innovation and Severe Misconception

Is There a Third Eid in Islam?

The text addresses the practice of celebrating a new Eid, likely referring to Eid Milad-un-Nabi (the Prophet's birthday), and identifies it as a grave religious error.

The Mistaken Belief and the Islamic View

The author argues that celebrating an invented Eid is a serious mistake for several reasons:

  • Violation of Religious Principles: In Islam, Eids are not optional or rational observances; they are entirely dependent on the clear instructions of Allah and His Messenger (PBUH). Inventing a new Eid is considered a bid'ah (a religious innovation).

  • False Measure of Love: This new Eid is presented as a symbol of love for the Prophet (PBUH). The author refutes this, stating that true love for the Prophet (PBUH) is measured by following his Sunnah, living according to his excellent example (Uswah Hasanah), and striving to eliminate religious innovations, not by celebrating a fabricated festival.

  • Ideological Distortion: Although this practice may seem harmless, it is a profound ideological distortion. The author also points out that the processions (jashne julūs) and other baseless acts performed during these celebrations further compound the error.

  • Focus on Deeds and Piety: The author reminds readers that Allah accepts sincere deeds (amal) and taqwa (piety), not external showmanship. Only following the Sunnah is acceptable to Allah, not bid'ah.

  • Following Foreign Customs: The author questions whether a practice adopted from a culture, such as that of Christians (whose ways Muslims pray to be guided away from in Surah al-Fatihah), can truly benefit the Muslim community.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, March 2012, www.alkawsar.com

A Mistaken Religious Ruling:

Are Children Excluded from Their Father's Inheritance if They Have a Different Mother?

The text addresses the mistaken belief that children from different wives of the same father are not all entitled to an equal share of his inheritance.

The Right to a Father's Inheritance

  • The Misconception: Some people believe that if a father has children with multiple wives, the children from different mothers are not entitled to the inheritance.

  • The Correct Ruling: The author clarifies that this is absolutely wrong. All legitimate children of the deceased father, regardless of whether they have the same mother or different mothers, are entitled to an equal share of the inheritance. The share is distributed according to the fixed proportions set by Islamic law.

The author cites the principle from the Quran, "For the male, the share of two females" (لِلذَّكَرِمِثْلُحَظِّالْأُنْثَيَيْنِ), as the guiding rule for all children.

The Right to a Mother's Inheritance

Similarly, a related misconception is that only the children from a mother's last husband are entitled to her inheritance. The author states that this is also false. All of a mother's children, from any of her husbands, are equally entitled to her inheritance without any distinction.

Source: Monthly Al-Kawthar, April 2012, www.alkawsar.com
